multichart._comment1: This filter MUST be first and must use this name
multichart._comment2: The values are computed by the client.

help.default: This filter allows you to select: 1) the count or rate of cases screened-in on the first day of the quarter or year (point-in-time data) or 2) the count or rate of opened and closed screened-in cases (cohort data). The ‘Overview’ selection shows the point-in-time data in the top bar graph and the cohort data in the bottom line graph.
help.sp_ihs_trends_counts: In the chart format, ‘Overview’ displays a bar graph of the count (or rate) of placement prevention service cases on the first day of the quarter or year (point in time data). The chart format also displays a line graph of the number of open placement prevention service cases and the number of closed placement prevention service cases for the entire month or year (cohort data). Each ‘Overview’ count or rate is available individually in the chart format. The table format returns all the ‘Overview’ data.
help.sp_ooh_wb_familysettings: The chart format provides a line graph of the percentage of children in one of three family settings—a state foster home, a private foster home, or with relatives/kin—on the first day of the year. The ‘Overview’ displays the percentage of children in all family settings, as well as those in a ‘non-family setting (e.g., group home).
help.sp_ooh_wb_siblings_by_year: With this filter you can examine whether all, some, of none of the siblings in family are placed into out-of-home care. The ‘Overview’ selection compares the three choices.

display.help: Age references the child’s/youth’s age at the time of placement in out-of-home care.
Age at exit references the age of the child/youth when s/he left out-of-home placement.
Age references the child’s/youth’s age in the selected years.

Age references the child’s/youth’s age at the time s/he was removed from their home and placed into out-of-home care (e.g., kinship care, foster care). Because the age categories are based on U.S. Census classifications, we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by age for the state or county.

Age references the child’s/youth’s age on a given date (i.e., the first day of the year or quarter). Because the age categories are based on U.S. Census classifications, we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by age for the state or county.
Age at the time the child/youth exited out-of-home placement uses modified developmental age categories. This age category includes youth through age 18.

This filter is used for the Screened-In Cases and Placement Prevention Services measures. It references the ages of the children in the household at the time the referral was screened-in or at the time the family was receiving placement prevention services. The age categories follow U.S. Census classifications, therefore we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by age category for the Division of Children and Family Services Offices.
You can select re-entry to out-of-home care from reunification, adoption, or guardianship. The default includes all three outcomes.
You can select exit from out-of-home care to reunification, adoption, guardianship, emancipation or other. The default ‘exit type’ includes reunification, adoption and guardianship.

You can select exit from out-of-home care to reunification, adoption, guardianship, emancipation or other (e.g., transfer to another Washington State authority). The default selection is exits to all five outcomes.
This filter returns data on the number of siblings in a family in order to assess the configuration of siblings who are placed together.
This filter returns data on the groupings (i.e., all, some, or none) of siblings placed in out-of-home care.
You can filter for relative/kinship placements only or for all types of placement (foster care, kinship care, group home, etc.).

Race and ethnicity categories are based on U.S. Census classifications. Races are above the line, ethnicities are below the line. Because the Census provides data on the races and ethnicities within geographic divisions, we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by race or ethnicity for the state, county, or Division of Children and Family Services Office. Note that each household or child has a race AND an ethnicity.

help.default: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their initial or first placement setting on the first day of a given year or quarter (point in time data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_rates: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their initial or first placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_exits: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their initial or first placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_counts: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their initial or first placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_reentry: The percentage of re-entries into out-of-home care can be filtered by the child's/youth's initial or first placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_outcomes: The percentage of exits from out-of-home care can be filtered by the child's/youth's initial or first placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.

help.default: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their longest placement setting on the first day of a given year or quarter (point in time data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_rates: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their longest placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_exits: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their longest placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_counts: This filter provides counts or rates of children/youth in their longest placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_reentry: The percentage of re-entries from out-of-home care can be filtered by the child's/youth's longest placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_outcomes: The percentage of exits from out-of-home care can be filtered by the child's/youth's longest placement setting during a given year or quarter (cohort data). See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.

display.help: Cohort data for household with children who are placed following in-home services are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘all’ in-home service cases. Let’s assume an in-home services was opened in March and June of 2008 and then again in February 2009. The ‘first’ in-home service case would be in (March) 2008 and ‘all’ in-home service cases would include both the cases in 2008 and the case in 2009. See Interpreting Type of Count.
where

Cohort data for counts and rates of children in out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’, ‘unique’, and ‘all’ children entering out-of-home care. Let’s assume we are counting by year (not quarter) and the child’s first entry into out-of-home care was in (March) 2008 through (November) 2008, their second entry began in (February) 2009 and ended shortly after in (May) 2009, and their third entry began in (August) 2009 and ended in (December) 2009. This child’s ‘first’ entry would be in (March) 2008, their ‘unique’ count of entries would include (March) 2008 and (February) 2009 and their ‘all’ count would be their unique count plus the second entry into out-of-home care in (August) 2009. ‘See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for counts of children in out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’, ‘unique’, and ‘all’ children exiting out-of-home care. Let’s assume we are counting by year (not quarter) and the child was in out-of-home care for three time periods: (March) 2008 to (November) 2008, (February) 2009 to (May) 2009, and (August) 2009 to (December) 2009. This child’s ‘first’ exit would be in (November) 2008, their ‘unique’ count of exits would include (November) 2008 and (May) 2009; and their ‘all’ count would be their unique count plus the second exit from out-of-home care in (December) 2009. ‘See Interpreting Type of Count.

Point in time data for counts and rates of children in out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘all’ children in out-of-home care. The point in time counts reference the first day of the year or quarter. Let’s assume we are counting years and the child’s first stay in out-of-home care started in (December) 2005 and ended in (February) 2007 and their second stay began in (December) 2007 and ended in (January) 2008. This child would be IN their ‘first’ stay on the first day of 2006 and the first day of 2007; the count of ‘all’ stays would be the count of the first stays plus the first day of 2008. ‘See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for children who are re-referred after the first investigation or who re-enter out-of-home care are aggregated into counts of unduplicated or unique re-referrals or re-entries and first or initial re-referrals or re-entries within the selected time interval. See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for children who re-enter out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘unique’ exits from out-of-home care. Let’s assume a child was in out-of-home care from (March) 2008 to (November) 2008 and from (February) 2009 to (May) 2009. This child’s ‘first’ exit would be in (November) 2008 and their ‘unique’ exits would include their first exit plus (May) 2009.See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for children who enter out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘unique’ entries into out-of-home care. Let’s assume a child was in out-of-home care from (March) 2008 to (November) 2008 and from (February) 2009 to (May) 2009. This child’s ‘first’ entry would be in (March) 2008 and their ‘unique’ entry count would include their first entry plus (February) 2009.See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for households with children who are re-referred following a prior screened-in referral are aggregated into counts of ‘first’ and ‘unique’ screened-in referrals. See Filters Explained for a ‘count type’ example. . See Interpreting Type of Count.

Data for counts/rate of screened-in cases are aggregated into counts/rates of ‘first’ and ‘all’ screened-in cases per household. ‘First Screened-In Case’ is the first ever referral that was screened-in for investigation/assessment. ‘All Screened-In Cases’ includes all referrals that were screened-in for investigation/assessment during the selected quarter or year. See Interpreting Type of Count.

Data for counts/rate of placement prevention service cases are aggregated into counts/rates of ‘first,’ ‘unique,’ and ‘all’ placement prevention service cases per household. ‘Total Placement Prevention Service Cases’ is a point in time count, meaning placement prevention service cases are counted on the first day of the year or quarter. ‘Opened Cases’ and ‘Case Closures’ are cohort counts, meaning placement prevention service cases are counted as being opened or closed during that quarter or year. See Interpreting Type of Count.

In Washington State, anyone who has reasonable cause to believe that a child has suffered abuse or neglect can, in good faith, make a report. Mandated reporters (above the line) are required by law to report concerns to the local Children’s Administration office or to law enforcement. ‘Law Enforcement Officer’ includes ‘Correction Personnel’.  Adults below the line are mandated to report if they are “residing with a child suspected to have been severely abused”. ‘Other’ reporters include reports by the subject or the victim. ‘All’ includes all reporters, mandated or not.

There are five primary entry points, i.e., first point of contact with Children’s Administration. Currently, the Data Portal can return data for Child Protective Services (CPS) and ‘All’ entry points. CPS provides 24 hour, seven days a week intake, screening, and investigative services for reports/ referrals of alleged child abuse and neglect.

An allegation of child abuse, neglect, or any maltreatment can come from any person (mandated reporter or not). Social workers have the option of entering up to four types of maltreatment per case, meaning there will be more allegations than cases. Neglect and physical abuse comprise the bulk of allegations; due to the severity of sexual abuse, it is also included in the allegation filter. To determine how many cases have no allegations, subtract ‘Any of the Above’ from ‘All (With or Without Allegation).’

An allegation finding means that, more likely than not, the Children’s Administration Child Protection Services (CPS) investigator determined that child abuse or neglect did occur. To determine how many cases have no legal finding, subtract ‘Any of the Above’ from ‘All (With or Without Legal Finding).’

An out-of-home care episode begins with a formal custody date and ends with a formal discharge date to a permanency outcome. A child/youth in out-of-home care can have MULTIPLE PLACEMENTS WITN AN EPISODE. If, for example, you selected a four year period to examine, and within that time the child/youth had two episodes, with two placements in each episode, s/he would have had four placements.

An out-of-home care episode begins with a state custody date and ends with a federal discharge date. Multiple placements into out-of-home placement settings can occur within a single episode. This filter allows you to determine how many episodes are greater than 7 days, 60 days, 1 year, or 2 years.

The courts become involved when there is a dependency proceeding or action. A dependent child is one who was abandoned, abused or neglected, or whose parents are incapable of adequately parenting. In this filter, ‘Immediate Dependency’ means a petition was filed within 45 days of the start of the out-of-home episode and ‘Eventual Dependency’ means the petition was filed more than 45 days after the start of the episode.

Some placement prevention services are paid by Children’s Administration (CA) and some are not covered. Examples of paid services include case management and certain behavioral rehabilitation services. CA-paid services can be directly linked to a child or a family. Services that are not paid for by CA: cannot be linked to a child or family; are purchased in bulk; or are provided by a service provider or any entity other than CA (e.g., health care, employment services).

The service categories above the line are generally in-home services. The services below the line tend to be services for families with children in out-of-home care. More about the following services can be found in the Glossary: Family Focused Services, Therapeutic Services, Receiving Care, Family Home Placements, Behavioral Rehabilitation Services, Other Therapeutic Living Situations, Specialty Adolescent Services, Respite Care, Sexually Aggressive Youth, Adoption Support.

The six Department of Social and Health Services (DSHS) budget categories include all the major IN-HOME budget categories. DSHS codes are provided for people familiar with Children's Administration budget categories.

The entry cohort you are following is that group of children/youth who entered out-of-home care in the chosen year. ENTRY COHORT YEAR choices begin January 2000 and end on the most recent year for which we have data. Because nearly all children/youth in out-of-home care have achieved permanency or turned 18 years old within four years, the default year is set approximately four years earlier than the most recent year and results are returned for up to 48 months.
The cohort entry year TODO

This filter allows you to follow households with at least one child involved in a screened-in referral from 2006 through the most recent date for which there is data.  Data on the percent of households with children re-referred are returned for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year(s).

This filter allows you to follow households that received in-home services from 2009 to the most recent data for which there is data. Data on the percent of households (with at least one child placed in out-of-home care) are returned for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year(s).

The exit cohort is that group of children/youth who exited out-of-home care in the selected years. ‘Exit Cohort Year’ choices begin January 2000 and end on the most recent year for which we have data. The default date is set four years earlier than the most recent year and returns result for 48 months. If the selected year(s) are less than 48 month in the past, the line graph and the data will be truncated.

This filter follows the cohort of households which received their (first) investigation/assessment within the cohort year(s) selected. Data on the percent of children re-referred are returned for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year.
Not used?

The exit cohort is that group of children/youth who exited out-of-home care in the selected year(s). ‘Exit Cohort Year’ choices begin January 2000 and end on the most recent year for which we have data. The default date is set four years earlier than the most recent year and returns result for 48 months. If a year that was less than 48 ago is selected, the line graph and the data will be truncated.

This filter follows the cohort of households which received in-home services in the selected cohort year(s). Data on the percent of children placed in out-of-homecare are returned for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year.
The minimum and maximum date for which reliable data are available are indicated on the slide bar. You can adjust the bar to any range; the default is the full date range.
The minimum and maximum date for which reliable data are available are indicated on the slide bar. You can adjust the bar to any range; the default is the full date range.
This is the county the data suggests the child/youth lived in prior to removal. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.
This is the county the child/youth was placed in on this date. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.
The location of the child/youth when s/he received a federal discharge (reunification, adoption, guardianship) or was emancipated (turned 18 years old).
The location of the child/youth when s/he received a federal discharge (reunification, adoption, guardianship) or was emancipated (turned 18 years old). TODO

This is the county where the referral was screened-in for investigation or the county where the services are received.  You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.
There are 43 DCFS Offices (Division of Children and Family Services) offices in Washington State.
